optical sensors,[5,6] photoelectric devices,[7] control of supramolecular chirality,[8,9] and catalysts for asymmetric synthesis.[10–14] Besides the physical method by using a linear polarizer and a quarter-wave plates, circularly polarized light may be directly generated from chiral luminescent materials, thus preventing energy loss during the transition process between the plates. In order to achieve circularly polarized luminescent (CPL)-activity, the usage of luminescent organic or inorganic materials is generally required. For example, to obtain organic CPL-active materials, combining a chiral moiety with a luminophore by a covalent bond is the most general pathway. In such a way, a tediously long synthesis process is sometime inevitable. Moreover, the CPL-activity of the obtained chiral emitters is unpredictable. Similarly, inorganic CPL-active materials also require arduous inorganic syntheses by capping
chiral reagents on prefabricated nanomaterials. To date, very few cases of CPL-active inorganic materials have been reported.[15–22] Thus, the development of a general and versatile approach for fabricating CPL-active materials becomes emergent.
Self-assembly provides a powerful solution for precisely controlling the arrangement of building blocks and enhancing certain properties.[23–25] For example, self-assembly can significantly amplify the circular polarization of some CPL-active materials.[26] In addition, not only chiral, but also achiral chromphores can be endowed with CPL activity via self-assembly.[27,28] An intriguing recent approach for fabricating CPL-active materials through the self-assembly pathway, associating the guest of luminophore to an assembled chiral host, called as “chiral host–achiral luminescent guest,” has been widely demonstrated.[21,22,29–31] The chiral host can coassemble with achiral luminophores, subsequently endowing the achiral component with CPL activity. Based on such an efficient approach, various organic and inorganic materials can be embedded into a chiral host, which generates numerous CPL-active materials.
In developing CPL materials, a key issue is obtaining a high luminescence dissymmetry factor (glum), which is used to quantify the level of CPL, glum = 2 × (IL − IR)/(IL + IR), where IL and IR are the intensity of the left- and right-handed circularly polarized emissions, respectively (as detailed below). The maximum value of |glum| is 2, which means completely left or right circularly polarized light.[32] Thus, pursuing large glum value is one of the most urgent issues in CPL research. Self-assembly has been proved to be efficient in amplifying the glum in many cases,
Currently, the development of circularly polarized luminescent (CPL) materials has drawn extensive attention due to the numerous potential applications in optical data storage, displays, backlights in 3D displays, and so on. While the fabrication of CPL-active materials generally requires chiral luminescent molecules, the introduction of the “self-assembly” concept offers a new perspective in obtaining the CPL-active materials. Following this approach, various self-assembled materials, including organic-, inorganic-, and hybrid systems can be endowed with CPL properties. Benefiting from the advantages of self-assembly, not only chiral molecules, but also achiral species, as well as inorganic nanoparticles have potential to be self-assembled into chiral nanoassemblies showing CPL activity. In addition, the dissymmetry factor, an important parameter of CPL materials, can be enhanced through various pathways of self-assembly. Here, the present status and progress of selfassembled nanomaterials with CPL activity are reviewed. An overview of the key factors in regulating chiral emission materials at the supramolecular level will largely boost their application in multidisciplinary fields.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Polarization of light can be regarded as part of a high-level visual perception since it contains a lot of potentially useful information about such visual features like the material content, surface shape, and local curvature of objects.[1] Among the different kinds of polarized light, circular polarized light is considered to be special, and has drawn great attention due to its potential application in 3D displays,[2,3] chiroptical materials,[4]

Herein, we focus on the recent progress of self-assembled CPL-active materials and highlight the intriguing findings for amplifying the luminescence dissymmetry factor, aiming at providing inspiration for boosting the development of chiroptical materials. We also try to analyze the future prospects of the applications, which would help researchers to develop more effective CPL-active materials (Figure 1).

sections.heading: 2. Basic Concepts Related to CPL
sections.text:
Generally, natural light and most other common sources of visible light can be regarded as unpolarized light, in which their emissions are uncorrelated and polarization varies rapidly in time. Actually, the definition of unpolarized light is much stricter. It can be described as a mixture of two independent oppositely polarized streams, each with half the intensity. In other words, unpolarized light is fully polarized at every point. Once there is more power in one of these streams than the other, the unpolarized light turns to polarized. Due to the difference of the wave vector in the direction perpendicular to the propagation of the light wave, polarized light can be simply classified into partially, elliptically, linearly, and circularly polarized light.[40–42] Figure 2A shows the typical preparation of procedure for circularly polarized light from unpolarized light via the combination of a linear polarizer and a quarter-wave retarder. The main drawback of this approach is the loss of energy during the transition process through the plates.[43–45]
Based on these concepts, the mechanism of electronic circular dichroism (CD) and circularly polarized luminescence (CPL) measurements can be simply illustrated, as shown in Figure 2B,C. CD spectroscopy originates from the differential absorption of right- and left-handed circularly polarized light.[46] During the measurement, left- and right-handed circularly polarized light are alternately generated from a xenon lamp, and subsequently pass through a chiral material. The CD spectrum can be obtained through the comparison between the original and remaining light intensity. Therefore, the Cotton effect is always located at the absorption position (Figure 2B).
On the other hand, the excitation light source for a CPL measurement is generally unpolarized, in order to eliminate the influence of polarized light for the detection of true CPL signals.[47–49] The emission intensity of left- and right-handed CPL generated by the chiral luminescent sample is different when the material is excited.[32,50] The CPL spectrum reflects the intensity difference of the emission; thus, it always accompanied with the emission spectrum (Figure 2C). It should be noted that the CD signals of a chiral luminescent system do not ensure the observation of CPL signals. On the contrary, CPLactive materials normally display the Cotton effect.
As shown in Figure 2B,C, the final optical spectra are both based on the intensity of circularly polarized light. Consequently, the magnitude method of CD and CPL are similar. sections.heading: 3. CPL in Self-Assembled Supramolecular Systems
sections.text:
Generally, a typical CPL material contains two major moieties: a chiral part and a luminescent part. If the chiral luminescent system is completely unassembled or in monomer state, these
two parts should be merged together or closely connected via covalent bonds. For an assembled system, the chiral information can be realized from the asymmetric arrangement of the building blocks.[53] Therefore, not only chiral luminescent molecules, but also achiral luminescent compounds, can possibly generate CPL directly. Figure 3A–C summarizes three typical approaches to realize CPL in self-assembled supramolecular systems: i) chiral assembly of chiral luminescent molecules (Figure 3A); ii) chirality transfer between the chiral molecules and the achiral luminescent molecules (Figure 3B); iii) breaking of symmetry of the achiral luminescent molecules in nanoassemblies (Figure 3C).

sections.heading: 3.1. CPL from Chiral Luminophores
sections.text:
For chiral luminescent molecules, there are two cases: 1) the chiral moiety is luminescent, and 2) the chiral moiety is nonluminous but contains a luminescent moiety within one molecule, i.e., the chiral part and the luminescent part are covalently bonded (Figure 3A). It is generally accepted that in both these two cases, chiral supramolecular systems, which usually display CPL properties, are easily formed. Figure 3D shows several typical chiral moieties from point chirality to axial, planar, helical, and propeller chirality. While this method is frequently adopted for the fabrication of CPL materials, it usually needs a tedious synthetic way to obtain the corresponding compounds. In addition, it should be noted that a number of factors including the spacer between the chiral center to the assembly site, the strength of the noncovalent bonds, and the competition of the chiral and achiral interactions may affect the emission of CPL. CPL properties from chiral luminescent molecules, as an intriguing research issue, have received increased attention in recent years. We will not deal much with such a case here, as excellent accounts and reviews are already available.[6,47,54–57]

sections.heading: 3.2. CPL from an Assembly of Chiral Molecules and Achiral Luminophores
sections.text:
Another important approach for fabricating CPL-active materials is the combination of chiral molecules with achiral luminophores. The induced chirality of the achiral luminophores from the chiral components is of utmost importance. Obviously, one of the greatest merits of this approach is that almost all luminophores, both chiral and achiral ones, can be endowed with CPL activity, which opens up great possibilities for the design and fabrication of CPL-active materials. Another obvious merit of these complex systems is that instead of a tedious organic synthesis, a simple mixing of the chiral molecules with commercially available achiral luminophores can produce various CPL-active materials.
Considering that the luminophores are achiral, the obtained CPL signal can be assigned to the induced chirality through coassembly with a chiral matrix, which has been extensively demonstrated in previous works and reviews.[53,58–60] Here, the description of “chirality transfer” means that the chiral sense of the chiral component is transferred to the achiral components to form a complex system that exhibits supramolecular chirality. During the chirality transfer, the interaction between the chiral host matrix and the achiral components plays a very important role, and the design of molecules with matched bonding sites and their cooperation are of utmost importance.[58] All types of noncovalent interactions, such as hydrogen bonds, electrostatic interactions, host–guest interactions, metal–ligand coordination, as well as hydrophobic interactions, can be utilized to perform the chirality induction.[53,59,61,62] In addition, chirality-confined spaces or environments can also endow achiral components or aggregates with chirality. For example, chiral α-cyclodextrin can induce the achiral azobenzene to exhibit a strong CD signal due to the strong host–gust interaction.[63,64] Based on the Kirkwood– Tinoco equation, the induced chirality is caused by the dipole– dipole interaction between a transition moment of a guest molecule and those of the bonds composing the chiral host molecule.[63]
Figure 4A shows a general approach for the fabrication of 1D nanoassemblies with CPL properties from achiral dyes or aggregation-induced emissive compounds (AIEgens).[30] As illustrated in Figure 4A, a C3 symmetric chiral gelator can individually form hexagonal nanotube structures due to the intrinsic chirality of the substituted glutamate moieties.[65] It was found that the achiral luminophores can be encapsulated into the confined nanotubes via organic gelation, and achiral AIE luminophores aggregate during the coassembly process, which shows enhancement in emission intensity and can emit circularly polarized light by direct excitation. Meanwhile, the handedness of the CPL is controlled by the supramolecular chirality of the nanotube. As shown in Figure 4B,C, mirror-imaged CPL signals from 425 to 595 nm, covering the full color range from blue via green and yellow to orange-red, can be achieved by simply changing the doped dyes.[30]
Besides the chiral encapsulation effect that is illustrated in Figure 4A, the electrostatic interactions between chiral nanotemplates and charged nonchiral dyes can be employed to realize the induction of strong and tunable CPL.[31] As
shown in Figure 4B, three glutamic acid derivatives with different charges were first synthesized to provide chiral ordered nanotemplates. When a nonchiral fluorescent dye, for example, NK-2012, was mixed with the amphiphilic molecules, the anionic nature of this dye was anticipated to promote electrostatic interactions with cationic chiral nanotemplates. The induced supramolecular chirality of the achiral dyes was also confirmed by temperature-dependent measurements. For example, combining the absorption and CD spectra, the temperature-dependent changes indicates that the achiral dyes are H-stacked aggregates with chiral assemblies.[31] Due to the electrostatic interaction and the enhanced chirality of the template, these binary systems exhibited strong CPL activities, and the largest |glum| values were up to 0.102. This is an extraordinarily high value for glum in dilute solution systems.[66] Apart from glum values, a considerable enhancement of the fluorescence quantum yield was observed for the binary systems. For example, the mixed system exhibited 47 times higher fluorescence intensity (Φ = 0.075) than that of NK-2012 alone (Φ = 0.0016).[31] This enhancement of fluorescence intensity can be explained by the high rotational resistive microenvironment caused by the chiral nanotemplates, which is similar to the aggregation-induced emissive mechanisms as shown in Figure 4A. Therefore, with both the chiral nanotemplate and nanotube, a series of achiral molecules, either AIE compounds or dyes can be coassembled into CPL materials with tunable CPL color and handedness.
Due to the feasible and vast number of fluorescence molecules, the CPL properties of fluorescence, or in other words circularly polarized fluorescence (CPF), have been widely investigated. However, its long-lived counterpart, circularly polarized phosphorescence (CPP) at room temperature, is not that common.[67–71] Figure 5 gives an example of long-persistent CPP from chiral organic ionic crystals.[72] As shown in Figure 5A, a pair of chiral organic ionic crystals are incubated from achiral terephthalic acid (TPA) and chiral (R/S)-phenylethylamine (PEA). The emission peaks in Figure 5B located at 425 and 500 nm could be confirmed as long-lifetime phosphorescence, indicating that the triplet excitons could generate and decay in a radiative process. Upon UV irradiation, sapphire emission could be observed from the obtained crystals (Figure 5D). After removal of the excitation source, the emission changed to greenish, and faded off in several seconds, suggesting the remarkably long-persistent phosphorescence property. During the CPL measurement, strong CPL signals were observed, as shown in Figure 5C. The CPL signals were split into two peaks at wavelengths of about 370 and 500 nm, which might be attributed to the fluorescence and phosphorescence constituents, respectively. In addition, the observed CPL signals were found to follow the chirality of (R/S)-PEA: R-type crystals showed right-handed CPL emission, while S-type crystals displayed left-handed CPL. Single-crystal structure analysis results suggested that the achiral TPA molecules could possess chiral structures with a mirror relationship in cocrystals with PEA in R and S configuration, as shown in Figure 5E. Intriguingly, the planar and twisted carboxyl groups in TPA result in totally opposite directions. The twisted carboxyl groups were closer to the amine groups than the planar carboxyl groups, indicating a more intense interaction in the ionic domains. Based on the

This work opened up the new research topic of long-lifetime CPP, cocrystalized from chiral and achiral components. The room-temperature long-persistent phosphorescence could extend the application of CPL to various fields, like bioimaging and bioencoding. Besides, this kind of circularly polarized phosphorescence will broaden the research field of CPL. More importantly, simple small organic compounds could be endowed with chirality, as well as CPL, through a coassembly procedure. In addition, the chiral and achiral components can be flexibly tuned. sections.heading: 3.3. CPL from Exclusively Achiral Molecules
sections.text:
In the above two approaches, an intrinsically chiral component, either in molecular form or as a trace chiral trigger, is required for the generation of CPL. However, not only chiral molecules, but also completely achiral molecules, can form chiral supramolecular assemblies, thus providing the possibility for the fabrication of CPL materials from exclusively achiral luminophores. This situation results from spontaneous symmetry breaking, which generally needs an asymmetric environment during selfassembly.[53,73–75] Figure 6A shows an intriguing example of an achiral ionic polymer and rhodamine B, which shows CPL activity under mechanical stirring.[76] Moreover, the CPL signal was determined by the stirring direction: counterclockwise (CCW) stirring resulted in a positive sign, while a negative sign was induced by clockwise (CW) stirring. In order to verify the origin of the CPL, the corresponding spectra were recorded through the four different faces of the cuvette. Although the CPL magnitude was somewhat different, the CPL spectra recorded through the four different faces displayed a similar shape with the same sign in a series of measurements, indicating that the
stirring-induced chirality on a macroscopic level is transferable to rhodamine B. However, it should be noted that such CPL only can be observed during the stirring process. Once the stirring stopped, the sample turned out to be CPL-silent.[76]
In supramolecular gel systems, achiral C3-symmetric gelators have also been found to show excellent CPL performance. When these achiral gelators formed organogels, strong emission as well as the CPL were shown.[27,28] Although many achiral molecules have been reported to form chiral nanostructures and exhibit CPL activities via spontaneous symmetry breaking, only preferential chiral nanostructures (one enantiomer is more abundant than the other) were obtained, resulting in relatively weak and fluctuating CPL intensity.[28] On the other hand, the handedness of the CPL signals is still quite random in most systems from exclusively achiral molecules. To date, the supramolecular chirality in achiral systems can be controlled by adding some simple chiral dopants[27,78–80] and an external influence, such as a magnetic field, circularly polarized light, as well as the vortex motion generated by rotary evaporation or magnetic stirrers.[14,81–83] However, obtaining homochiral supramolecular assemblies (only one enantiomer) fabricated
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1900110
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900110 (8 of 33)
from achiral molecules is still very challenging, let alone controlling their CPL handedness without any chiral additives.
Very recently, by using a vortex-mixing-accompanied selfassembly strategy, near-unity homochiral entities with controlled handedness were obtained from exclusively achiral molecules (BTACA), as illustrated in Figure 6B.[77] The gelation process via heating and cooling of the achiral molecules in N,Ndimethylformamide (DMF)/H2O only resulted in racemic gels with almost-negligible CPL activities. However, if vortex mixing (created by a vortex mixer) is applied during the self-assembly process, near-unity homochiral assemblies with uncontrolled handedness were obtained. Combined with the real-time evolution of CD intensity under various vortex mixing times, it was found that vortex mixing during the nucleation stage was crucial for the chiral enhancement. This self-assembly process should be attributed to the nucleation–elongation model, which includes two stages: an initial nucleation process and a subsequent growth step.[84,85] Primary nucleation can induce
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1900110
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900110 (9 of 33)
the conversion of achiral monomers into small chiral aggregates via noncovalent interactions. The two enantiomers were found to be indistinguishable in terms of energy, and thus, they existed with equal probabilities.[86] These dimers gradually grew by capturing neighbor achiral molecules to form chiral assemblies. Since the primary nucleation of the two enantiomers was equivalent, a racemic gel was obtained finally. When vortex-mixing treatment was applied during self-assembly, the rapid generation of secondary nuclei reduced the concentration of monomers to a level at which the primary nucleation is suppressed. It is well accepted that the primary nucleation is a relative cumbersome process due to the kinetic barrier of reaching the critical nucleus.[87] Therefore, it is possible for the formation of nuclei of the opposite handedness as a result of the competition caused by vortex mixing. Consequently, one enantiomorph occasionally dominated the system, and the population of the chiral bias was gradually enhanced. However, there was no preference for the chiral bias. After that, subsequent supramolecular assembly can further amplify the initial chirality to give an almost homochiral polymer with either leftor right-handedness.
On the other hand, due to the dynamic feature of supramolecular assemblies, a small amount of aforementioned homochiral assemblies (10% molar ratio) can be used as chiral seeds and convert the racemic gels into homochiral suspensions with controlled handedness via a ripening process. A mechanism similar to attrition-enhanced Ostwald ripening should not be neglected, which might remove the competing lineages of the two enantiomers, leaving the seeds-determined ancestor for the entire system.[88,89]
It is still a big challenge to fabricate CPL-active materials from exclusively achiral compounds. The optional organic emitters that could show symmetry breaking during the selfassembly process are limited to several special molecular structures. However, this direction will absolutely open up a brandnew research topic for the exploration of CPL-active materials. Particularly, the symmetry breaking only occurs in selfassembled systems. Thus, it is now in the sophisticated stage by further design and control of molecular self-assembly. It is expected that appropriate molecular design just based on the C3-symmetric core, by introducing various emitters to the side chains, will produce various candidate achiral emitters. Various CPL-active assemblies might be obtained by controlling the process of self-assembly.

sections.heading: 4. CPL in Inorganic Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Besides organic materials, there has been a growing interest toward the development of inorganic materials capable of displaying CPL properties due to their fascinating properties.[18] A great challenge in CPL-active inorganic nanomaterials is the ingenious introduction of chirality. Since many inorganic materials do not have chiral centers, the modification of the chiral ligands on the surface of the nanomaterial provides an important way to endow inorganic materials with CPL properties. Incorporation of inorganic nanomaterials into a confined chiral space like protein cavity has also been proved as effective for the fabrication of CPL inorganic materials.[15] Hereafter,
we will give some examples of typical nanomaterials with CPL properties, which can be broadly classified into several dimensions from 0D to 3D.

sections.heading: 4.1. 0D Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Generally, 0D nanomaterials with chirality or CPL properties have been obtained by decorating with chiral capping reagents, which has been extensively reported.[17,90,91] The detailed mechanism can be assigned to the hybridization of the chiral molecular orbital of the chiral ligands and the electronic structure of the achiral core. Figure 7 shows a typical example of chiral-ligand-induced CD and CPL in achiral cadmium selenide quantum dots (CdSe QDs).[17] High-resolution transition electron microscopy (HRTEM) images of CdSe QDs before (diameter = 2.9 nm, Figure 7A,B) and after ligand exchange (Figure 7C,D) revealed the close packing of QD clusters. CPLactive CdS was once prepared from scratch in a nanocage of an apoferritin.[15] Here, through a chiral ligand, CPL in semiconductor QD nanocrystals was obtained, although the glum values are small (+0.003 and −0.004 for L-cysteine- and D-cysteinecapped CdSe QDs), as shown in Figure 7G. In addition, opposite CPL signals could be obtained for the two QDs having the capping cysteine ligand with opposite handedness. The calculation results qualitatively reproduced the experimental data and further suggested that the induced CD is mainly due to the hybridization of the ligand’s highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) with the QD valence-band states.[17]
Apart from the above example, however, it is still a great challenge to observe a CPL signal for QDs capped with chiral ligands. It appears that the selection of the capping ligand is crucial for the induction of CPL properties.[90] On the other hand, CPLactive 0D nanomaterials can also be achieved through supramolecular approaches. Different from the individual optical behavior of QDs, the observed CPL signal in this case should be assigned to the QD–chiral–matrix complexes. As shown in Figure 8, commercially available 3-mercaptopropionic-acidcapped QDs underwent a coassembly process with a glutamatebased chiral lipid in an ethanol/H2O mixture to form supramolecular gels with nanotube morphologies.[22] Mirror-image CPL signals from 400 to 750 nm can be achieved by simply mixing the chiral gelator with the achiral QDs (Figure 8A). Here, the wavelengths of the emission were regulated by different QDs, while the handedness could be controlled by the molecular chirality of the gelators. Moreover, by tuning the blending ratio of QDs with different colors, white circularly polarized emission was achieved. During the formation of the co-gel system, the electrostatic interactions between the carboxylate groups on the QD surface and the amine groups of the gelator are important for the chirality induction. A chiral host formed by a chiral gelator can provide a chiral space or environment through the formation of entangled networks, which will endow the guest achiral QDs with induced supramolecular chirality. In addition, the length of the spacer between the carboxylic acid and the thiol on the surface of the QDs is also curial. When 3-mercaptopropionic-acid-modified QDs (QDs-C3) were replaced by the 12-mercaptolauric acid (QDs-C12)-capped QDs, no CPL signal was observed, despite that the FTIR analysis proved the

existence of the same interactions between the QDs and the chiral gelators (Figure 8A). These results confirmed that the flexible long spacers prevented effective chirality transfer from the chiral nanotubes to the QDs-C12.[22]
Similarly, this strategy can be applied to endow other inorganic nanomaterials with CPL properties.[21,92] Lanthanidedoped upconversion nanoparticles (UCNPs), which can convert low-energy NIR light into high-energy UV or visible light (anti-Stokes shift) through the absorption of two or multiple low-energy photons,[93,94] have found diverse potential applications in many fields. As shown in Figure 8B, two kinds of achiral UCNPs, NaYF4:Yb/Er (UCNPs-Er) and NaYF4:Yb/Tm (UCNPsTm), were helically encapsulated into chiral nanotubes. In this case, upconverted CPL (UC-CPL) could be readily realized under the excitation of a nonpolarized 980 nm laser. Intriguingly, mirror-image UC-CPL signals covering a wide range, from 300 nm (UV part) to 850 nm (near-infrared), were observed.[92]
To realize the UC-CPL, the chiral arrangement of UCNPs was found to be critical and necessary. It should be noted that the unequal left- and right-handed UC-CPL were generated at a supramolecular level rather than the UCNPs monomers. For example, in the unassembled state (realized by changing the solvent), although the gelator has the inherent chirality due to the glutamate part, the chirality transfer from the chiral monomer to the UCNPs seems impossible. In such case, no UC-CPL was observed from the unassembled state of the chiral
gelator/UCNP mixtures. On the other hand, if the chiral gelator is replaced by an achiral gelator, which could form a micrometer-sized sphere structure that consisted of smaller spherules, it is hard to observe UC-CPL as well. These results indicate that the hollow structures of chiral tubes provide a confined space for the encapsulation of UCNPs, which is more effective than the sphere morphologies in the chirality transfer. Therefore, the arrangement of UCNPs along the chiral tubes might be crucial for the induced UC-CPL in this case. In addition, the ultraviolet parts of the UC-CPL generated from the co-gels can be used to trigger the enantioselective photopolymerization of diacetylene derivatives.[92]

sections.heading: 4.2. 1D Nanomaterials
sections.text:
As mentioned above, a chiral ligand was effective in endowing QDs with CPL activity.[17,95] This method also works very well in inducing nanorods to be CPL active. Recently, different sizes of L- and D-cysteine-capped CdSe-dot/CdS-rods (DRs) were synthesized via a postsynthetic ligand-exchange method.[91] Interestingly, their CD and CPL activities were first found to be sensitive to the intrinsic geometry properties and surrounding chiral medium, as illustrated in Figure 9A. In order to avoid complexity and redundancy, the absorption ratio of shell to core (ARSC), Ashell/Acore, is used to describe the geometry-dependent
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1900110
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900110 (11 of 33)
CD and CPL phenomena. As observed by the TEM images in Figure 9B, various ARSC values of CdSe/CdS DRs were prepared by tuning the sizes of the CdS shell and CdSe core, and their overall nanostructures transformed from 0D (QDs) to 1D (nanorods). The chirality transfer from l- and d-cysteine to CdSe/CdS DRs was proved by the corresponding CPL spectra (Figure 9C): the d-cysteine-modified DRs showed a positive CPL, while the l-cysteine-capped DRs exhibited negative CPL signals. More importantly, the fitting lines in Figure 9D reveal a close relationship between the ARSC and the absolute values of glum, in which higher ARSC values correspond to lower |glum| values and vice versa. In addition, the amount of l- and d-cysteine that is used for the ligand exchange and the following chirality transfer was also discussed. The spectra in Figure 9E,F revealed that the lowest excess amount of chiral cysteine molecules in the medium resulted in the highest |glum|. This result indicated that an excess of chiral ligands in the aqueous solution inhibited the CPL behavior of the superstructures instead of increasing the possibility of coupling with inorganic nanomaterials, which is usually neglected during bottom-up synthesis.[91]

sections.heading: 4.3. 2D Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Compared with chiral materials prepared from organic molecules, chiral inorganic nanomaterials exhibit refraction-based optical activities with prominent intensities, which might open new horizons in physical theory and macroapplications.
Therefore, there is an urgent requirement for chiral inorganic materials with a large scale, such as 2D nanosheets/ films. Several strategies, including engineered glancing-angle deposition[96,97] and sculpturing,[98–100] as well as duplication in nanocrystalline cellulose,[101–103] have been proposed for the fabrication of chiral inorganic films. Figure 10A presents scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images at varying magnifications of chiral nanostructured ZnO films synthesized using L-methionine as the structure-directing agent and zinc acetate hydroxide as the zinc source.[19] The transparent chiral nanostructured ZnO film with a smooth and uniform surface was composed of dozens of compactly arrayed bent nanoplates, almost vertically aligned from the surface of the substrate in an interval space of 50–200 nm, displaying inconspicuous circinate aggregates. The wide-angle X-ray diffractometry analysis suggested that ZnO crystals were grown in parallel along [0002] on the substrate (Figure 10B). The antipodal chiral nanostructured ZnO films exhibited a mirror-imaged CPL centered at 510 nm corresponding to the fluorescence maximum after excitation at 325 nm (Figure 10C,D). Besides the CPL properties, this chiral ZnO thin films exhibited multiple optical activities including prominent electron-transition-based and scattering-based optical activity, as well as Raman optical activities, simultaneously.[19]

sections.text:
When CPL nanomaterials are fabricated in a more hierarchical level, like 3D, the self-assembly of the inorganic building blocks

One prerequisite for high-level self-assembly is that both the size and shape of the basic units must be highly uniform.[104,105] However, such a requirement is difficult to achieve via the self-assembly process due to the coexistence of assembly and disassembly. Another challenge for the self-assembly of inorganic materials is that the assemblies should exhibit unique properties or functions, which is different from those of the individual building blocks.[106] Figure 11 shows a CPL-active crystalline nanocube composed of chiral gold clusters.[107] The structure of Au clusters was revealed by the single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SC-XRD) analysis. As illustrated in Figure 11A, three Au atoms in one cluster

connect with each other and form a regular triangle. The chirality originated from the PAuP bonds between each Au atom and a chiral biphosphine ligand. The Au clusters could be well dispersed in dichloromethane (DCM) and exhibit intense CD response. However, no CPL signals were observed in this well-dispersed state. After adding nonpolar n-hexane as antisolvent, the Au cluster started to assemble and uniform nanocubes appeared with an average edge length of 366 nm when the fraction of n-hexane reached 70% (Figure 11B,C). The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern proved the crystalline BCC packing pattern inside the nanocubes. Intriguingly, these nanocubes displayed strong CPL response centered at 583 nm (Figure 11D) and maximum glum values of about ±7 × 10−3 (Figure 11E). Both experimental and theory calculation results suggested that restricted intramolecular rotation and the ordered stacking of the chiral stabilizers in the crystalline lattices are crucial for the emergence of CPL properties.[107]
Although the luminescent components were alternatively organics (e.g., AIE dyes) or inorganics (e.g., quantum dots and perovskite nanocrystals), nearly all of the chiral components in CPL materials are organic. Recently, Jin and co-workers reported the first totally inorganic CPL-active system by a “luminescent guest–chiral host” strategy.[29] Using a simple two-step method of adsorption and calcination (400 °C for 2 h and 900 °C for 4 h), luminescent sub-10 nm lanthanide oxide (Eu2O3 or Tb2O3) nanoparticles (guests) were successfully encapsulated into chiral nonhelical SiO2 nanofibers (host). These lanthanide oxides displayed both circular dichroism optical activity and CPL signals. More importantly, this method can be extended to other transition-metal oxides (e.g., CuO, Fe2O3, and ZnO) as well as other inorganic hosts/guests to design new CPL-active systems.[29]

sections.heading: 5.1. Molecular Design
sections.text: Generally, most CPL nanoassemblies are fabricated through the bottom-up strategy. As a result, the molecular design of building blocks is of utmost importance to gain large glum values. Several crucial factors should be considered during the molecular design, such as where to introduce the chiral center and luminophores, and how to balance the different noncovalent interactions during self-assembly. Figure 12 shows the varied CPL performance of three kinds of molecules with similar structures.[110,111] As illustrated in Figure 12A, the 1D coordination polymers P1 feature the bis(dipyrrinato)metal(II) complex motif, which contains a bridging dipyrrin ligand between L1 and the Zn2+ ions.[110] Upon sonication, bulk solid P1 formed single fibers in organic media. However, there is no CPL signal due to the lack of chiral and luminescent motifs in the molecules. When chiral binaphthyl was introduced in the molecular design and connected one dipyrrin motif, only two ligands and one Zn(II) ion were connected via coordinate bonds (Figure 12B). As a result, both the CD and the CPL spectra suggested that (R/S)-M2 displayed a weak chiroptical response (Figure 12D,E). The average |gabs| and |glum| values for (R/S)-M2 are about 3.6 × 10−4 and 3.9 × 10−4, respectively. When two dipyrrins were symmetrically connected with the binaphthyl, chiral 1D coordination polymers could be formed in the organic solvent via the sonication process (Figure 12C).[111] The maximum length of the 1D coordination polymers was up to 3.19 µm long. It was found that the chirality was transferred from the chiral binaphthyl to the achiral dipyrrin. Intriguingly, the absolute magnitude of the CD and CPL signals was enormously enhanced, and the average |gabs| and |glum| values were up to 2.5 × 10−3 and 2.3 × 10−3, respectively. Therefore, the gabs of (R/S)-P2 was enhanced by 6.9 times and the glum was 5.9 times more intense than that of (R/S)-M2.[111]

sections.heading: 5.2. Assembly/Aggregation-Enhanced CPL
sections.text:
As stated above, supramolecular self-assembly can endow achiral chromophores with chirality, which shows the process

of CPL-activity from CPL-inactive materials. For the same reason, the controlled self-assembly of chiral chromophores would be one of the simple and efficient strategies adopted for the enhancement of glum.[26,112–114] However, from solution to the condensed phase, the CPL performance becomes even worse due to the fact that most fluorophores suffer from the aggregation-caused quenching (ACQ) effect, yielding a much lower or even no emission performance in the condensed phase. Fortunately, an exactly opposite phenomenon, aggregation-induced emission (AIE) was observed by Tang’s group.[115] As shown in Figure 13A, in order to solve the ACQ problems and achieve both high emission efficiency and large glum values, silole and mannose were selected as the AIE luminophore and the chiral component, respectively.[116] After natural evaporation of the solvent, the remaining solid displayed strong fluorescence under UV illumination (Figure 13B), and the fluorescence quantum efficiency in the solid thin-film state could reach as high as 81.3%, indicating typical AIE effects. Although no CD or fluorescence emission was observed in the solution state, the aggregated state samples showed a significantly enhanced CD and CPL. The helical assemblies emitted right-handed CPL with glum values ranging from −0.08 to −0.32 under different experimental conditions. To date, −0.32 is the largest glum value for pure organic compounds. After this ground-breaking work, assembly- or aggregation-induced enhancement of CPL has been reported in various nanomaterial system, including platinum(II) complexes,[117,118] chiral binaphthyl derivatives,[119] polymers,[114,120–123] leucine- and valine-containing luminophores,[124,125] perylene bisimides,[126,127] and so on.[26,128]

sections.heading: 5.3. Plasmon-Resonance-Enhanced CPL
sections.text:
The use of a metallic nanostructure has been demonstrated as one of the most common techniques to enhance fluorescence. Although the reported description of the metallic effect is varied, such as metal-enhanced fluorescence,[129] surface-enhanced fluorescence,[130] plasmon-enhanced fluorescence[131] and metal-induced fluorescence enhancement,[132,133] these modes can be attributed to the origin of surface plasmon resonances that are generated by the interaction between a photon and an electron at the metallic surface. It should be noted that plasmon resonance can dramatically alter the chiroptical properties of molecules near noble-metal surfaces such as plasmonic circular dichroism.[33,134,135] Figure 14 is an example of silver nanoparticles (AgNPs)-enhanced CPL properties of an anionic meso-tetrakis(4-sulfonatophenyl)porphyrin (TPPS) complexed with cationic surfactants.[33] As illustrated in Figure 14A, the dianion H4TPPS2− molecules first form
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1900110
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900110 (16 of 33)
chiral J-aggregates (TPPS)n in an acidic aqueous medium, and their chirality can be finely controlled by the electrostatic interaction with cationic chiral surfactants (DMEB). However, the CPL observation was very weak or at an undetectable level. After adding the citrate-capped AgNPs, the DMEB displaced most of the citrate bound to the surface of the AgNPs. The photographs in the inset of Figure 14C show that the fluorescence emission was enhanced about fivefold after the addition of AgNPs to the (TPPS)n–DMEB solution. As a result, a clear and detectable CPL signal was observed for this composite.[33] These changes in CPL intensities are closely related to the plasmon-induced electromagnetic enhancement responsible for other surface-enhanced optical phenomena such as surface-enhanced Raman scattering and surface-enhanced fluorescence.[136]

sections.heading: 5.4. CPL Amplified by Förster Resonance Energy Transfer
sections.text:
It is generally accepted that information transfer is multichannel in living organisms. The transfer of both chirality and energy at hierarchical assembly structures from molecular to macro-levels is crucial for their sophisticated functions.[137,138] Figure 15 shows an observation of both chirality and energy transfer in a self-assembly system based on a chiral donor and an achiral acceptor.[34,139] Unexpectedly, not only chirality transfer was observed in the complex, but also the intensity of CPL was significantly amplified during the energy transfer. The chiral gelator could self-assemble into an ordered lamellar structure through the hydrogen bond between the amide groups and π–π stacking. During the self-assembly process, chirality was transferred from the molecular level to the supramolecular level, resulting in CPL properties with a glum value of about ±1.1 × 10−2. When the chiral gelator mixed with achiral acceptors, the weak π–π stacking interaction between the donor and the acceptor caused the coassembly, in which the acceptor was inserted into the nanohelix (Figure 15A). Consequently, the coassembly process caused further chirality transfer from the nanohelix to the achiral acceptors. In addition, due to energy transfer and the helical alignment of the chromophores, the composite assemblies emitted CPL from the achiral acceptor unit. Remarkably, as shown in Figure 15A, the observed CPL glum for the acceptor, by exciting the donor, is about ±3 × 10−3 (at 320 nm), while the glum values decreased to ±1.2 × 10−3 by directly exciting the acceptor (at 400 nm). These results indicated that the glum values of CPL showed more than 2.5 times amplification through the energy-transfer process. This might be attributable to the enhanced acceptor
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1900110
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900110 (17 of 33)
emission via the energy transfer, which seems to further cause the amplifiaction of glum values.[34]
To further investigate the amplification of CPL based on energy transfer, we recently reported a cooperative chirality and sequential energy transfer in a supramolecular light-harvesting nanotube, which contained a cyanostilbene-appended glutamate hydrogelator (CG) and two achiral acceptors, thioflavin T (ThT), and acridine orange (AO).[35] As illustrated in Figure 15B, the chiral gelator could self-assemble into helical nanotubes exhibiting both supramolecular chirality and CPL. When two achiral acceptors were coassembled with the CG nanotubes, the chiral information could transfer to both of the acceptors. On the other hand, the excitation energy could be transferred from the nanotubes to ThT but only be sequentially transferred to AO. During this process, in the CG/ThT/ AO triad system, when exciting the donor CG or intermediate donor ThT, a stepwise-amplified CPL was observed compared with that by directly exciting the second acceptor AO.
Based on these experimental results, a possible mechanism for such energy-transfer-associated CPL was proposed. CPL is obtained when unpolarized light is used to excite a donor CG. However, the CPL energy will be transferred in the presence of acceptors, resulting in a new CPL ascribed to the acceptor. On the basis of a recent theoretical calculation by Bene et al., the helicity in fluorescence from a rotating donor dipole can be conserved after the energy- and helicity-transfer process (hFRET).[140] In the example of Figure 15B, the helicity of the
fluorescent donor CG may be transferred to the acceptor ThT, thus amplifying the glum of the ThT. In addition, compared with excitation by unpolarized light (glum = 3.3 × 10−3), the l-CG/ ThT system achieved amplified glum (1.89 × 10−2) when using circularly polarized light to excite it.[12,141] These results indirectly suggested that the helicity in the donor fluorescence can be transferred to the acceptor and subsequently amplifies the glum.[35] It is understandable that when energy transfer results in manifestations of chirality by an acceptor, cognate with effects in the donor, that it might seem that chirality, in some sense, accompanies the energy-transfer process. The mechanism about why and how the CPL is enhanced during the energy-transfer process is still unclear at present, and is currently under detailed exploration.
Nevertheless, this kind of energy-transfer-enhanced CPL truly opens up a brand-new research topic for the development of CPL-active materials. Only one chiral component is enough to induce the CPL emission in these assembled systems, and all of the induced CPL signal comes from the achiral emitters. Thus, molecular design and combination in this system will definitely produce a huge reservoir of CPL-active materials. First, if the chiral host assemblies are nonluminous, the as-formed assemblies could serve as a chiral template, while various other achiral emitters could be embedded or encapsulated into the chiral host. By modifying the energy transfer between the guest achiral emitters, various CPL-active materials can be achieved. Second, if the chiral host assemblies are

Third, the host assemblies can be designed as an achiral one. sections.heading: 5.5. Photon Upconversion Based on Triplet–Triplet Annihilation
sections.text:
Photon upconversion based on triplet–triplet annihilation (TTA-UC) is a promising approach to realize a higher-energy emission with excitation at a lower-energy light.[142–145] This process has a wide variety of applications such as solar-cell energy conversion,[94,146–148] photocatalysis,[149] photodynamic therapy,[150,151] and bioimaging[152,153] due to its high efficiency, noncoherent excitation source, and tunable excitation and emission wavelengths. Generally, the mechanism of the TTA-UC process is illustrated in Figure 16A.[36] At the beginning, the triplet state of the sensitizer is populated by intersystem crossing (ISC) after being excited by lower-energy photons, and then the triplet–triplet energy is transferred from the sensitizer to the acceptor to provide the triplet state of the acceptor. Finally, triplet–triplet annihilation of two acceptor triplets generates one acceptor at the ground state and one acceptor at the excited singlet state, and upconverted fluorescence is irradiated when the excited acceptor comes back to the ground
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1900110
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900110 (20 of 33)
state. As shown in Figure 16A, the CPL-active enantiomers binaphthyldiamine moiety with two 4-(10-phenylanthracen9-yl)phenyl groups was used as the acceptor, while an achiral Pt(II) octaethylporphyrin (PtOEP) was used as the sensitizer. As expected, the enantiomers showed mirror-image CD and CPL signals due to the axial chirality of the binaphthyl linker and the emitting 9,10-diphenylanthracene groups. When the chiral luminophore and the PtOEP sensitizer were mixed together with the molar ratio of 200/1 in toluene solution, upconverted CPL (UC-CPL) in the blue-light range was observed, excited by a green laser, and this was the first time that UC-CPL was demonstrated. Despite the UC-CPL emission increasing gradually, in line with laser intensity enhancement, the glum was almost the same, suggesting the inherent property of molecular chirality of the chiral acceptor. However, as shown in Figure 16D, the glum value for the UC-CPL excited by the 532 nm laser was 20-fold larger (±4 × 10−3) than the downconversion CPL excited at 360 nm (±2 × 10−4), which showed that TTA-UC can enhance the CPL.[36] Based on Equation (9), the amplification of glum in TTA-UC systems can be explained in two aspects. On the one hand, it is proposed that CPL can be achieved by populating the emitting state indirectly, either by inter- or intramolecular radiationless energy transfer, which could significantly influence the µgn with a negative effect.[32] On the other hand, the triplet–triplet-annihilation process could cause electron spin polarization, which further amplifies the magnetic-dipole transition moment (mgn), which would be positive for the increase of glum values.[36,154] The amplified magnetic-dipole transition moment and depressed electric-dipole moments resulted in the increase of CPL glum in the TTA-UC system.
UC-CPL represents a new notion that combines CPL with photon upconversion. Although the mechanism of amplified glum is not clear, the exploration of various approaches to promote the level of UC-CPL is urgent. The integration of TTA-UC with CPL thus renovates the field of chiroptical functional materials. In terms of functionalization, it is expected that the UC-CPL has potential application in the asymmetric photochemical reaction or novel chiroptical switch materials. Thus, UC-CPL from near-infrared (NIR) light to visible or ultraviolet (UV) region is of vital significance. For example, circularly polarized light could work as an effective chiral source for initiating enantioselective photochemical reactions. Thus, the UC-CPL system would open up an intriguing potential for a new journey in the asymmetric photochemical reaction. On the other hand, UC-CPL in supramolecular systems possesses a stimulus-responsiveness to various external stimuli, including temperature, light, pH, and mechanical force. Thus, it is expected to lead to the achievement of novel chiroptical switches based on UC-CPL.

sections.heading: 5.6. Liquid-Crystal-Enhanced CPL
sections.text:
As an intermediate phase between solid crystal and isotropic fluid, liquid crystals (LCs) are a kind of versatile material with long-range orientational order, which show fascinating properties. After doping with chiral elements, chiral nematic LCs (N*LCs) generally self-organize into a helical structure with 1D periodicity, which manifests as intrinsic selective Bragg reflection of light.[155,156] In principle, optical and electronic
excitation of materials containing helically arranged luminophores can generate circularly polarized emission. In liquidcrystalline systems, CPL mainly originates in the selective reflection from the helical pitch of the cholesteric liquid-crystalline phase. So far, using emissive N*LCs has been proved to be an effective method to amplify the glum value.[37,38,155,157–160] However, there is no report of the amplification of the glum value of UC-CPL. Figure 17 shows the first example of enhanced UC-CPL emission in N*LCs.[39] As shown in Figure 17A, the N*LCs were obtained by blending a chiral emitter with an achiral nematic liquid crystal, which was proved by the typical fingerprint texture through polarizing optical microscopy (POM) images. What should be kept in mind is that the direction of the CPL signal in N*LCs was opposite to that in solution, because the handedness of an N*LC was determined by the CPL signal direction, and right-handed N*LCs were induced by an R chiral emitter, while a negative CPL was observed in solution. However, the glum of the chiral emitter in the N*LCs was determined to be as high as ±0.2, about three orders of magnitude higher compared with the dilute solution state (Figures 16C and 17C). By adding a triplet sensitizer (PtOEP), efficient TTA-UC emission was observed, excited at 532 nm, which had the same cyan-colored emission as observed by excitation at 365 nm (Figure 17B). As expected, the N*LCs exhibited mirror-image UC-CPL signals with glum of ±0.04. More importantly, the glum value of UC-CPL in the N*LCs was significantly amplified by one order of magnitude compared with the dilute solution sample (Figures 16D,17D).[39]
The significance of CPL in chiral liquid crystals is threefold. First, by adding a chiral emitter into an achiral nematic liquid crystal, it is easy to achieve chiral emissive liquid crystals with excellent CPL-activity. The corresponding glum shows exponential amplification compared with that in the solution state. Second, after integrating with UC-CPL, just simple blending with a small amount of a triplet sensitizer, highly efficient TTA-UC could be achieved in the N*LCs. Moreover, efficient triplet energy diffusion and long migration length will promote the efficiency of TTA-UC in liquid crystals. More importantly, UC-CPL would be obtained without tedious synthesis of a UC donor or acceptor showing liquid-crystal behavior. Third, by considering that photon upconversion can significantly amplify the dissymmetry factor glum, the UC-CPL in chiral liquid crystals could further enhance this novel property. From the above case, it is obvious that the upconverted dissymmetry factor showed one order of amplification compared with that in the solution state. This strategy will promote the design and fabrication of chiroptical materials with not only better UC-CPL emission but also rational emission efficiency for more practical application.

sections.heading: 5.7. CPL Enhanced by an Achiral Component
sections.text:
CPL in systems based on two or more components is usually dependent on thermodynamic control, because CPL can occur from either integrated coassembly or separated self-sorting, which is more sophisticated compared with single-component systems. Not only the chiral component but also achiral molecules can generate and amplify the CPL properties.[161–163]
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1900110
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900110 (21 of 33)
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1900110
Figure 18A shows the example of fluorescence-inert achiral molecules assisting the enhancement of CPL.[164] The building blocks are l-histidine-based molecules substituted by naphthalene (a luminophore) at the α- or β-position, which are abbreviated as α-NapHis and β-NapHis, respectively. It was found that β-NapHis could neither form a supramolecular gel in any solvent nor show CPL. On the contrary, α-NapHis formed a supramolecular gel with CPL properties upon sonication. The calculated glum was ±5.0 × 10−4 at 370 nm. In addition, the α-NapHis could form coassemblies with achiral benzoic acids. Although benzoic acid is neither chiral nor fluorescent, the two-component assemblies show enhanced CPL. The largest CPL glum for this complex is ±3.0 × 10−3. The possible mechanism for this CPL enhancement is illustrated in Figure 18. Due to the π–π stacking between the naphthalene and H-bonding between the urea and imidazole motifs, the α-NapHis formed a bilayer structure. For the coassemblies, the XRD results indicated that benzoic acid and a-NapHis first formed C3-like structures between the imidazole and carboxylic acid groups, which further self-assembled into hexagonal structures. The tighter π–π stacking in the hexagonal packing resulted in a better chiral transfer of the coassemblies, which might further increase the (IL – IR) values.[164] On the other hand, the total fluorescence intensity (IL + IR) decreased after adding benzoic acid. Based on Equation (7), an enhancement of the CPL was observed. This mechanism is in agreement with those reports that lower (IL + IR) values could lead to higher CPL.[32,50] In three-component systems; for example, one chiral and two achiral components, chirality-transfer-induced CPL can be also realized, and achiral molecules usually play a significant role in the chiral coassembly. Figure 18B gives an example of a three-component system including a chiral amino acid, achiral
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1900110 (22 of 33)
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1900110
nucleobase, and a dye.[161] Unexpectedly, the achiral nucleobase (guanine (G) or adenine (A)) was found to trigger the helix of Fmoc–Glu and transfer its chiral sense to the achiral cationic dye (thioflavin T, THT). ThT is one of the most popular fluorescent probes, and has already been used for the detection of amyloid fibers and also to study gel formation.[165,166] When this second achiral molecule is introduced, it expresses helicity at the nanoscale level and further transfers the chirality to the fluorescent molecules, thus leading to a strong CPL. X-ray diffraction patterns indicate an obvious lamellar structure with a d-spacing of 2.36 nm. However, this d-spacing is larger than one molecular length of Fmoc–Glu (1.34 nm) but shorter than two, suggesting a bilayer structure of Fmoc–Glu with an overlapping Fmoc moiety. Based on the above results, the nucleobase might laterally attach on the bilayer surface of the Fmoc– Glu. The purine bases interact with two alternate glutamic acids through hydrogen bonding, and the bulky purine base may lead to torsion of the neighboring Fmoc–Glu molecules.

sections.heading: 6. The Application of CPL-Active Materials
sections.text:
As mentioned above, great efforts have been devoted to the exploitation of new CPL materials and the enhancement of glum. Although the CPL levels achieved up to now from organic and inorganic materials generally are small, substantial applications are already reported. The most interesting applications of CPL-active materials involve the biology-related field and chiral optoelectronics. Due to the high luminescence quantum yield, solution-processability, and excellent chiroptical properties of organic chiral emissive compounds, circularly polarized organic light-emitting diodes (CP-OLEDs) have been attracting much more attention in recent years. Herein, we address the most prominent fields for the application of CPL, such as
bionanomaterials, CPL displays, switches, sensing, and probing. Some optical devices and biological applications based on CPL will also be discussed.

sections.heading: 6.1. Bionanomaterials
sections.text:
Although the natural light emitted by the sun is in a fully depolarized form, it turns into strongly polarized light after travelling through the Earth’s atmosphere. This polarization effect is attributed to the scattering and reflection of light by the abundance of particulate matter and geometrically shaped surfaces in the atmosphere.[167] Moreover, the degree of polarization is closely dependent on the time of day and angle of the sun, and the strongest polarization occurs during the sunrise or sunset, when the sun is near the horizon. Due to the ubiquitous occurrence of polarized light, many natural species are sensitive to circularly polarized light, after millions of years of evolution.[168–170] One typical example is the beetle Chrysina gloriosa (or Plusiotis gloriosa), which selectively reflects left-handed CPL and displayed a brilliant metallic appearance.[171] As can be seen in Figure 19A, the C. gloriosa beetle has a bright green

color and silver stripes can be seen in unpolarized light or with a left circular polarizer (left), but the green color is mostly lost when observed with a right circular polarizer (right). The optical microscopy image of the C. gloriosa beetle shows that the exoskeleton is composed of hexagonal cells with diameter of about 10 µm. In addition, laser scanning confocal microscopy indicates a spiral structure with a conical form on the free surface of the beetle exoskeleton. This selective reflection of CPL has been attributed to be similar to the optical response of cholesteric liquid crystals.[172] More recently, inspired by the CPL from glossy scarab beetles, cellulose films have been found to transform incident light into passive left- and right-handed CPL with viewing-side-dependent handedness and |glum| values up to 0.87, and spontaneous emission transforms to right-handed CPL emission with |glum| values up to 0.68.[173]
Apart from the left-handed CPL reflector of beetles, the cuticle of Plusiotis resplendens reflects both left- and right-handed CPL, as seen in Figure 19B.[174] A further study indicated that a halfwave retardation plate sandwiched within the helix results in this unique optical effect. Based on the sandwiched helicoidal structure in the P. resplenden beetle, a new mechanism for an optical diode is proposed as illustrated in Figure 19B. This optical diode works on the basis of an optical heterojunction anisotropic structure consisting of an anisotropic layer sandwiched between two cholesteric-liquid-crystal layers with different helical pitches. Dispersion curves show that the photonic bandgap positions depend on the propagation direction, showing optical-diode behavior.[174] Due to its easy fabrication and electrotunability, the optical heterojunction anisotropic structure is promising in the development of photonic devices.
Besides animals, helicoidal architectures have already been found in the plant kingdom. As shown in Figure 19C, Pollia condensata can maintain a strong blue color despite its age and drying conditions due to Bragg reflection of helicoidally stacked cellulose microfibrils that form multilayers in the cell walls of the epicarp.[175] The higher-magnification TEM cross-sectional image indicated that the helicoidal structure composed of a series of twisting arcs, which is consistent with the individual segments of cellulose microfibrils. Color-selective transmission and reflection of light occur due to the difference in the propagation of light when the wavelength matches the helical pitch of the stack structure. Therefore, the periodicity of the helicoid and average reflective index lead to the reflection occurring in the striking blue coloration.[175]
Different from the scarab beetles, where CPL is entirely based on reflection from optical architectures, the circularly polarized body signals of stomatopods (commonly known as mantis shrimps) are produced by the dichroic properties of astaxanthin molecules, which are oriented vertically within the antennal scale.[167] More importantly, the mantis shrimp has adapted its ability to visually distinguish circularly polarized light, which is different from the linear-polarization vision used by all other organisms.[177] As shown in Figure 19D, a recent report demonstrated that torsional rotations are used to actively enhance the ability to recognize the polarization of light.[176] In total, stomatopods have the capacity to view and filter ultraviolet, visible, and polarized light (both LPL and CPL) through a set of compound eyes, which are composed of highly specialized and spectrally tuned photoreceptors and optical structures.[178]

sections.heading: 6.2. CPL Sensing and Probing
sections.text:
To develop chiral optical sensors and probers, the chiral nature of CPL is the key factor. As mentioned above, CPL is a type of chiroptical phenomenon that consists of an unequal intensity of left- and right-handed circularly polarized light (i.e., IL ≠ IR), found in chiral luminescent systems. On the contrary, nonpolarized luminescence can be considered as a combination of equal amounts of left and right circularly polarized light (i.e., IL = IR), observed in achiral or racemic luminescent systems. Based on these intriguing difference in optical chirality, Figure 20 presents a potential application of CPL for object identification in sensor technology.[179] In this case, the chiral probe contains two chiral imidazole moieties at the 1,6-positions through ethynyl spacers, where the probe can self-assembly into chiral stacks with either P or M helicity upon coordination to metal ions such as Zn2+ (Figure 20B).
Due to the excitonic interactions after self-assembly,[180] the complex shows strong CPL signals. Conversely, nontarget species, such as Rhodamine 6G, display nonpolarized luminescence (IL ≠ IR), and thus can be eliminated by CPL measurement. As shown in Figure 20C, two samples were prepared for an object-identification experiment, one containing the nontarget species (Rhodamine 6G) only, while the other containing the chiral probe, target analyte (Zn2+), and Rhodamine 6G (nontarget species). In the conversional photoluminescence mapping image, they cannot be visibly distinguished due to the Rhodamine 6G exhibiting a similar yellow emission at 550 nm as chiral probes. However, significant variations can be observed in the CPL mapping, intense CPL signals in the region of Zn2+ and chiral probes with Rhodamine 6G, while no CPL signal can be detected in the area with Rhodamine 6G only.[179]
As noted above, CPL-based spectroscopy on the one hand effectively avoids a fluorescence background, and on the other hand provides another level of resolution compared with the conventional unpolarized emission spectrum. However, it is still a great challenge for quantitative detection by using CPL emission. One feasible approach is the use of a ratiometric probe, which is commonly based on a self-calibration process from two excitation or emission signals.[181] Therefore, the CPL probe should have two different CPL emitters in a single structure, and at least one of them could be able to interact with an external stimulus and further have optical responsivity (Figure 21A).[182] On the other hand, the (usually linear) relationship between the ratio of those two chiroptical motifs and the appropriate analyte concentration should be carefully designed for the CPL probe. Figure 21C shows the first synthesis of an organic monomolecular emitter, which was used as a CPL-based ratiometric probe for quantitative detection. This CPL probe was synthesized based on stapled ortho-oligo(phenylene)ethynylene (Figure 21B), which was previously reported as a CPL emitter due to carbophilic interactions with Ag(I)-sensitivity.[183] In addition, the pyrene motif, which is functionalized with stereogenic carbons, results in a second CPL emitter in the same structure, and thus a ratio between two CPL responses was achieved. As shown in Figure 21D, the first CPL signals, corresponding to the oligo-(phenylene) ethynylenes, were located at around 390 nm, while the second signal presented at around 515 nm was attributed to the

Therefore, the CPL response in terms of ∆I (IL − IR) diminishes in the presence of increasing amounts of Ag(I) for both signals. In addition, the ratio of ∆I (400 nm)/∆I (500 nm) shows a linear response with Ag(I) content, which conforms with the requirements for quantification.[182]

sections.heading: 6.3. CPL Switches
sections.text:
It should be noted that the CPL probes and sensors discussed above can be regarded as reversible switches once the target analytes are released from the emitter. For example, CPL switches based on reversible metal-ion coordination have already achieved.[184] To date, a large number of CPL switches have been developed, such as pyrene-based switches,[185,186] helicene-based switches,[187,188] and those based on sterically overcrowded unsymmetrical thioxanthenes and their analogues.[189,190] However, many of these switches have limited individual CD or CPL signals. Here, Figure 22A provides an example showing quadruple reversible switches based on the chiroptical signals in CD and CPL, and even their chiral nanostructures.[191] Besides the well-known fulgides,[192] diarylethenes,[193,194] azobenzenes,[195,196] spiropyran and its derivatives are the most widely studied photochromic compounds.[197] The closed form of spiropyran can be transformed into the open form (merocyanine) under UV-light irradiation, and the backconversion can be accelerated by excitation in the visible band or a simple heating process. As expected, the reversible chiroptical properties were achieved when the spiropyran moiety was attached with the chiral dialkyl glutamides. As shown in
Figure 22A, by alternating UV and visible light, CPL signals exhibited ON/OFF properties. Together with reversible UV–vis absorption and fluorescence, these spiropyran-based molecules exhibited quadruple optical and chiroptical switches.[191]
In Figure 22A, the photochromic spiropyran is connected with the chiral motif through a covalent bond. On the other hand, by using the coassembly strategy, the CPL switch can be also realized via the coassembly of achiral dyes and a chiral component with photochromic properties. As shown in Figure 22B, a photosensitive cinnamic acid derivative (l- or dCG), which could be dimerized along with a large change in molecular packing, can successfully switch the nanostructure from a superhelix to a nanokebab, as well as having supramolecular chirality.[198] Moreover, these helical nanostructures can serve as matrixes to convey their helicity to fluorescent achiral dyes (CBS) and emit CPL. Upon irradiating with UV light (365 nm), these superhelices turned into nanokebabs, and both the helicity and CPL were inverted. Interestingly, the CPL was found to follow the helicity of the chiral nanostructure rather than the inherent molecular chirality. Since the gel formation was thermally reversible, all the changes above in chiral nanostructure, helicity, and CPL can be repeated through alternative photoirradiation and heating/cooling procedures. Thus, by using the coassembly strategy, switches between different chiral nanostructures along with inversion of supramolecular chirality and CPL are successfully realized.
During the preparation of CPL materials, many factors, including ions, concentration,[186] temperature,[199] external force, pH, solvent polarity,[28,200] photoirradiation,[189] and orientation, can affect the CPL properties. Conversely, CPL switches have been realized by appropriately changing these

Figure 22C shows one example reported of ON/OFF CPL switching but without any change in fluorescence.[204] As shown in Figure 22B, due to the steric effects of the substituents, the (R)-binaphthyl could induce the formation of (R)-bipyridyl. By attaching the OMe groups covalently to the binaphthyl unit at the 3,3′-positions, it is expected that the protonated bipyridyl could form hydrogen bonds with the OMe oxygen, and thus result in a chirality inversion from the (R)-bipyridyl to the (S)-bipyridyl. During this process, the florescence that originated from the binaphthyl unit would not change. DFT results demonstrated that the two intramolecular hydrogen bonds could stabilize the conformation and further facilitate a drastic conformational change. Interestingly, the deprotonated sample did not display CPL, although its FL intensity and wavelength were indistinguishable before and after adding 10 equiv. trifluoroacetic acid (TFA). The CPL signal was recovered with the |glum| of 1.6 × 10−3 after the addition of triethylamine (Et3N). This result indicated that the ON/ OFF CPL arose from the excited-state conformations of the binaphthyl unit, in which the dihedral angle at the excited state appeared to contribute significantly.[204]

sections.heading: 6.4. CPL Displays
sections.text:
One of the especially promising applications of CPL materials is the fabrication of circularly polarized organic light-emitting diodes (CP-OLEDs).[119,205] In OLED displays, a polarizer and a quarter-wave plate are generally required as an antiglare filter to reduce reflectance from the surroundings, but these filters result in ≈50% energy loss emitting from the device.[206,207] In CP-OLEDs, efficient electroluminescence can be extracted without energy loss due to the polarizer filter to save energy. Moreover, high-contrast 3D displays can be achieved with CPOLED devices.[206,208–211] So far, the highest dissymmetry factor values for electroluminescence (gEL) are shown in Figure 23.[212] Poly(9,9-di-n-octylfluorenyl-2,7-diyl)-alt-(benzo[2,1,3]-thiadiazol4,8-diyl)] (F8BT) was used as a conjugate polymer, doped with a right-handed chiral dopant (R5011) with a high helical twisting power >100 µm−1, as an emitting layer (Figure 23A). The detailed OLED structure and energy levels for the materials are illustrated in Figure 23B,C. The largest gPL (dissymmetry factor for photoluminescence, which is equal with glum) and gEL values were −0.72 and −1.13 at λ = 546 nm for the optimum experimental conditions (Figure 23D–F). Although CPL is well established both technically and theoretically,[213,214] the understanding of

circularly polarized electroluminescence (CPEL) is still insufficient, especially at the macroscopic level. It has been found that the twist angle (θT) plays an important role on the values of gPL and gEL. For example, as shown in Figure 23G, it is very clear that the difference of the intensities passing through left- and right-handed circular polarizer diminish at θT = 170°. In order to further reveal the mechanism for the larger dissymmetry factor, systematic calculations were performed, and the stacking model is illustration in Figure 23H. The quantitative results indicated that the retardation and twist angle of the emitting layer and degree of the linear polarization from the emitted light are the key features for the high dissymmetry factor in this twisted stacking system. In addition, the recombination (emission) zone within the emitting layer is also crucial for the large values of gPL and gEL.[212]
Recently, materials with thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) properties have been developed as new-generation emitters to fabricate highly efficient OLEDs.[215] Due to of their small energy gap, 100% internal quantum efficiency can be theoretically reached by the efficient upconversion of excitons from the triplet (T1) to singlet (S1) states through reverse intersystem crossing.[216–218] Basically, in order to minimize the energy gap between the singlet and triplet states (∆EST), most chiral TADF molecules reported so far have been designed with a steric hindrance, which allows the donor (D) and acceptor (A) moieties to twist. The chiral unit with point chirality, BINOL, trans-1,2-diaminocyclohexane, and the chiral[2.2]-paracyclophane skeleton can be used to endow a TADF emitter with CPL.[211,219–221] However, due to the inherent difficulty of merging CPL and TADF properties in small organic molecules, only a few chiral TADF molecules have been successfully used as emitters to construct CP-OLEDs. Figure 24A gives the first example of CP-OLEDs with CPEL based on TADF materials.[209] Aromatic-imide-based TADF enantiomers, named (+)-(S,S)-CAICz and (-)-(R,R)-CAI-Cz were found to display mirror-image CD and CPL spectra, indicating that the chiral unit has successfully induced the TADF unit to produce chirality both in the ground and excited states. Notably, the CP-OLEDs based on these chiral TADF enantiomers not only achieve high EQE values of up to 19.7% and 19.8%, but also exhibit CPEL with opposite gEL signals of –1.7 × 10−3 and 2.3 × 10−3, respectively. Almost at the same time, a series of binaphthalene-containing luminogenic enantiomers with AIE and delayed fluorescence properties was designed and synthesized (Figure 24B).[206] The incorporation of chiral units into the peripheries of AIEgens is expected to achieve CP-OLEDs with both high gEL and EQE. Compared with a toluene solution, the neat film samples had an amplified CPL intensity with average |glum| values of 0.020–0.042. CP-OLEDs fabricated using the doped and neat films of these enantiomers exhibited high EQE of up to 9.3% and 3.5% and gEL of up to +0.026/–0.021 and +0.06/–0.06, respectively. The nondoped (neat films) CP-OLEDs show higher gEL and much smaller current efficiency roll-off because of the stronger AIE effect. In addition, the electroluminescence maximum of the doped film can vary from 493 to 571 nm by altering the donor unit.[206]
