sections.heading: 7. Conclusion and Perspective
sections.text:
CPL-active materials have drawn increasing interest due to the introduction of efficient synthesis and chiral self-assembly in various systems. It is important to recall the development of CPL materials. Since the l970s, chiral lanthanide complexes showing CPL-activity have been widely reported due to the large circular polarization resulting from the large magnetic-dipole transition moment. In recent decades, traditional chiral organic emitters have been synthesized and reported because of their various advantages, including flexible molecular design, high quantum yields, tunable wavelengths, and excellent processability, while the application fields have also been extended. Now, by introducing the design of new fluorescent materials and the concept of self-assembly, CPL-active materials have developed rapidly. Herein, we have highlighted recent progress in CPL-active materials fabricated through self-assembly or in nanoassemblies. It has been seen that the flexible self-assembly approach can extend the material categories, enabling systematic design and fabrication of various CPL materials. These developments are based on two points. One is the molecular design, which needs the combination of chirality and luminescence. From the point of view of chiral emissive materials, the concept of ACQ and AIE has been greatly developed and researchers can more easily design chiral materials showing CPL activity. The other is that the self-assembly approach provides a wide platform for research of CPL-active materials. Besides self-assembly from chiral emitters, many of the components, either chiral or achiral, can be fabricated into nanoassemblies. For example, based on various noncovalent bonds such as the host–guest interaction, π–π stacking, H-bonds, and so on, a chiral host can endow an achiral luminophore with CPL activity. Analogously, an achiral luminophore can be embedded or encapsulated into a chiral entity, and the achiral luminophore is thereby endowed with the CPL property. This is not only useful for organic systems but also for inorganic systems. Moreover, self-assembly provides a way of not only obtaining CPL activity but also of enhancing the dissymmetry factor. Thus, self-assembly could work as a flexible approach for achieving CPL-active materials. This method largely extends the category of CPL-active materials, which will definitely open up a new research field.
It is also imperative to combine energy-transfer-amplified circular polarization with self-assembly-regulated CPL activity. Energy transfer has been confirmed as an efficient pathway for amplifying the glum value, and it is now in the sophisticated stage by further design and control of energy transfer modes, including Förster resonance energy transfer, radiative energy transfer, and photon upconversion. To attain a maximized glum value with enhanced luminescence quantum yield, comprehensive design and regulation of the arrangement of the chiral emitters are necessary. The hybridization of energy transfer with self-assembly would provide an excellent strategy for developing highly efficient CPL-active materials. In addition, the theoretical mechanism of energy-transfer-amplified circular polarization in self-assembled systems is not yet fully understood: it will require the close collaboration with theoretical scientists. On the other hand, this also opens up a new research topic: energy-transfer-amplified circular polarization. We envisage that this topic is worth deep discussion. Thus,
future directions will involve a next-generation mechanism “energy-engineering-enhanced CPL” in CPL-active materials. By flexible tuning of chiral donor–acceptor systems, more efficient CPL-active systems are worth pursuing.
The research of CPL-active materials has been extensively expanded by the introduction of self-assembly and energy engineering. Although its applications have been discussed here, the development of CPL applications in information storage, imaging and sensing, and displays and devices are still in its infancy; further effort should be greatly devoted. We hope that the present work will help to seed and stimulate the research area of CPL-active materials, driving further development in chiroptical science.

In order to achieve circularly polarized luminescent (CPL)-activity, the usage of luminescent organic or inorganic materials is generally required. For example, to obtain organic CPL-active materials, combining a chiral moiety with a luminophore by a covalent bond is the most general pathway. In such a way, a tediously long synthesis process is sometime inevitable. Moreover, the CPL-activity of the obtained chiral emitters is unpredictable. Similarly, inorganic CPL-active materials also require arduous inorganic syntheses by capping chiral reagents on prefabricated nanomaterials. To date, very few cases of CPL-active inorganic materials have been reported.[15–22] Thus, the development of a general and versatile approach for fabricating CPL-active materials becomes emergent. Self-assembly provides a powerful solution for precisely controlling the arrangement of building blocks and enhancing certain properties.[23–25] For example, self-assembly can significantly amplify the circular polarization of some CPL-active materials.[26] In addition, not only chiral, but also achiral chromphores can be endowed with CPL activity via self-assembly.[27,28] An intriguing recent approach for fabricating CPL-active materials through the self-assembly pathway, associating the guest of luminophore to an assembled chiral host, called as “chiral host–achiral luminescent guest,” has been widely demonstrated.[21,22,29–31] The chiral host can coassemble with achiral luminophores, subsequently endowing the achiral component with CPL activity. Based on such an efficient approach, various organic and inorganic materials can be embedded into a chiral host, which generates numerous CPL-active materials. In developing CPL materials, a key issue is obtaining a high luminescence dissymmetry factor (glum), which is used to quantify the level of CPL, glum = 2 × (IL − IR)/(IL + IR), where IL and IR are the intensity of the leftand right-handed circularly polarized emissions, respectively (as detailed below). The maximum value of |glum| is 2, which means completely left or right circularly polarized light.[32] Thus, pursuing large glum value is one of the most urgent issues in CPL research. Self-assembly has been proved to be efficient in amplifying the glum in many cases, Currently, the development of circularly polarized luminescent (CPL) materials has drawn extensive attention due to the numerous potential applications in optical data storage, displays, backlights in 3D displays, and so on. While the fabrication of CPL-active materials generally requires chiral luminescent molecules, the introduction of the “self-assembly” concept offers a new perspective in obtaining the CPL-active materials. Following this approach, various self-assembled materials, including organic-, inorganic-, and hybrid systems can be endowed with CPL properties. Benefiting from the advantages of self-assembly, not only chiral molecules, but also achiral species, as well as inorganic nanoparticles have potential to be self-assembled into chiral nanoassemblies showing CPL activity. In addition, the dissymmetry factor, an important parameter of CPL materials, can be enhanced through various pathways of self-assembly. Here, the present status and progress of selfassembled nanomaterials with CPL activity are reviewed.
